Fertilizer and Pesticides

 

# Empirical View

# Fertilizer

# Fertilizer consumption per hectare in developed countries over the long run – Max Roser1

Full screen view Download Data
# Consumption of fertilizers by world regions – Max Roser2

Full screen view Download Data
# Fertilizer use by developing regions and type (nitrogen, phosphates, potassium in kg/ha), 1961-1999 – FAO3

# Price index of fertilizer, 1957-2000 (index: 2000=1) – Lomborg4

# World fertilizer prices in real terms, 1972-2003 – Heisey and Norton (2007)5

# Global map of phosphorus fertilizer application rates (kg per ha of gridcell area) – Potter, Ramankutty, Bennett, Donner (2010)6

# Global map of nitrogen fertilizer application rates (kg per ha of gridcell area) – Potter, Ramankutty, Bennett, Donner (2010)7

# World map of average annual nitrogen balance (pounds per acre) – National Geographic8

# Pesticides

The following graph shows the increase over the very long run.

# Total global pesticide production and global pesticide imports, 1940s-2000 – Tillman et al. (2002)9

# Estimated worldwide annual sales of pesticides (herbicides, insecticides, fungicides and others) in billions of dollars, 1960-1999 – Agrios (2005)10

# Annual usage of the various types of pesticides (in millions of pounds of active ingredient) and annual cost of pesticides (in millions of dollars) in the United States, 1980-1999 – Agrios (2005)11

# Average pesticide consumption (per unit area of agricultural land) in EEA member countries, 1988-1996 – European Environment Agency (2011)12

# Results of residue monitoring on domestic and imported foods by the Food and Drug Administration, 1988-1994 – Agrios (2005)13

Legend: green line – no pesticide residues, blue line – residues within legal limits, brown line – residues that were over the tolerance allowed by the Environmental Protection Agency

# Pesticide residue levels in human adipose tissue and human milk in USA, 1970-1983, United Kingdom, 1963-1983, and Japan, 1976-1985 – Simon (1996) – The State of Humanity14

# Total world pesticide consumption by world region, 1994-1997 – Heisey and Norton (2007)15

# Correlates, Determinants & Consequences

# Fertilizer

# Fertilizer use and cereal yields in sample countries, 1989-1992 – Dyson (1996)17

# World fertilizer use and grainland area per person, (1950-94) – Brown (1995)18

# Grain production in Australia, China, South America, and United States relative to nitrogen fertilizer use, 1961-2002 – Hatfield and Prueger (2004)19

# Pesticides

# Loss of food production due to diseases, insects and weeds – Agrios (2005)20
Attainable crop production (2002 prices)$1.5 trillion
Actual crop production (-36.5%)$950 billion
Production without crop protection$455 billion
Losses prevented by crop protection$415 billion
Actual annual losses to world crop production$550 billion
Losses caused by diseases only (14.1%)$220 billion

# Late blight of potato and the Irish famine: itinerary of the potato blight – Agrios (2005)21

The map below shows the itinerary of the advance of the potato blight between June, when the blight was first detected in Belgium, and the end of October 1845, by which time it spread from Italy to Ireland and from Spain to the Scandinavian countries.

# Map of the history of spread of ergot of sorghum, caused primarily by the fungus Claviceps africana, around the world – Agrios (2005)22

# Data Quality & Definition

The UN’s Food and Agricultural Organisation gives the following definition of Pesticides23: ‘Pesticides refer to insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing, destroying or controlling any pest, including vectors of human or animal disease, unwanted species of plants or animals causing harm during or otherwise interfering with the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of food, agricultural commodities, wood and wood products or animal feedstuffs, or substances which may be administered to animals for the control of insects, arachnids or other pests in or on their bodies. The term includes substances intended for use as a plant growth regulator, defoliant, desiccant or agent for thinning fruit or preventing the premature fall of fruit, and substances applied to crops either before or after harvest to protect the commodity from deterioration during storage and transport.

Data Sources

# Fertilizer

The FAO Fertilizer Database is online here. It includes several datasets on fertilizers for countries and world regions since 2002.

The same organisation’s Fertilizer Archive goes back to 1961 and is online here. For the same time span the FAO publishes data in the Fertilizers Trade Values Database here.

# Pesticides

The FAO Pesticides Use Database is online here. It includes several datasets on pesticides for countries and world regions since 1990. The FAO’s Pesticides Trade Database goes back to 1961 and is online here.

  1. The data is taken from table 6.3 in Giovanni Federico (2008) – Feeding the World: An Economic History of Agriculture, 1800-2000. Princeton University Press. Here is the website of the book.

    The original data sources cited by the author are: 1890-1957: Germany: (1880, 1910, 1920, 1940, and I960) Historical Statistics 1975, series K193 and J53 (assuming an average content of nutrients 17.5%); Japan: (1898-1902, 1908-12, 1918-22, 1933-37, and 1958-62) Hayami and Yamada 1991, table A5. Belgium: (1895,1910, 1929, and 1960-61) Blomme 1992, table 48.
    Year 1937 is referred to as 1937-38 in the original source; likewise 1957 refers to 1957-58, and 1999 to 1998-00.

  2. The data is taken from the FAO’s Fertilizer Archive online here.
    It is the series on ‘Consumption (tonnes)’ of ‘Total Fertilizers’.

  3. This is taken from FAO (2002) – World Agriculture: Towards 2015/2030. Online here.

  4. This is taken from Lomborg (2001) – The Skeptical Environmentalist. Cambridge University Press. In this book it is figure 81.

    The original sources are IMF(2001) – Updates from International Statistical Yearbook, online here.
    CPI (2001) – Consumer Price Index 1913-February 2001; Washington, DC: Bureau of Labor. Online here.

    The author notes that the values for the years 1974 and 1975 were 4.3, and 5.0

  5. This is taken from Paul W. Heisey and George W. Norton (2007) – Chapter 53 Fertilizers and other farm chemicals in the Handbook of Agricultural Economics. Volume 3, 2007, Agricultural Development: Farmers, Farm Production and Farm Markets, pages 2741–2777. Online here.

    The data sources of the authors were: World Bank “Pink Sheets” and CIMMYT Economics Program database, urea and TSP prices; U.S. Department of Commerce, U.S. GDP deflator.

  6. This is taken from Potter, Philip, Navin Ramankutty, Elena M. Bennett, Simon D. Donner (2010) – Characterizing the spatial patterns of global fertilizer application and manure production. Earth Interact., 14, 1–22. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1175/2009EI288.1 Online here.

    The authors’ note: Values represent average over all crops across each 0.5° resolution in latitude × longitude grid cell.

    The data can be downloaded at the website of author Navin Ramankutty’s website (here).

  7. This is taken from Potter, Philip, Navin Ramankutty, Elena M. Bennett, Simon D. Donner (2010) – Characterizing the spatial patterns of global fertilizer application and manure production. Earth Interact., 14, 1–22. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1175/2009EI288.1 Online here.

    The authors’ note: Values represent average N applied over all crops across each 0.5° resolution in latitude × longitude grid cell.

    The data can be downloaded at the website of author Navin Ramankutty’s website (here).

  8. This is taken from National Geographic here.

  9. This is taken from David Tilman, Kenneth G. Cassman, Pamela A. Matson, Rosamond Naylor & Stephen Polasky (2002) – Agricultural sustainability and intensive production practices. Nature 418, 671-677 (8 August 2002) | doi:10.1038/nature01014 Online here.

  10. This is taken from George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here.

  11. This is graphs D and E from Figure 1-43 in George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here.

  12. This is taken from European Environment Agency (2011) – Environmental Signals 2000: Chapter 6 Agriculture. Online here.

  13. This is taken from George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here.

  14. This is taken from a chapter in Simon [Ed.] (1996) – The State of Humanity. Blackwell. The following sources are given by the author: USA and UK: UN Environment Programme, Environmental Data Report, London: Blackwell, 1987, 100-1; Japan: UN Environment Programme, Environmental Data Report, London: Blackwell, 1989, 196.

  15. This is taken from Paul W. Heisey and George W. Norton (2007) – Chapter 53 Fertilizers and other farm chemicals in the Handbook of Agricultural Economics. Volume 3, 2007, Agricultural Development: Farmers, Farm Production and Farm Markets, pages 2741–2777. Online here.

  16. The source is the FAO (2013) – Statistical Yearbook, online here.

  17. The source is Tim Dyson (1996) – Population and Food: Global Trends and Future Prospects. Routledge.

  18. This is taken from Lester R. Brown (1995) – Nature’s Limit (Chapter 1) from the State of the World 1995, Worldwatch Institute, Washington, D.C.. Online at the website of the FAO here.

  19. This is taken from J.L. Hatfield and J.H. Prueger (2004) – Nitrogen Over-use, Under-use, and Efficiency in New directions for a diverse planet: Proceedings of the 4th International Crop Science Congress Brisbane, Australia, 26 Sep – 1 Oct 2004 | ISBN 1 920842 20 9. Online here.

  20. This is taken from George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here.

  21. This is taken from George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here.

  22. This is taken from George N. Agrios (2005) – Plant Pathology, Fifth Edition. Academic Press. 952 pages. The website of the book is here. The original source given by the authors is R. Bandyopadhyay et al. (1998). Plant Dis. 82, 356–367.

  23. This is the definition given by the UN’s Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) in their glossary that is online here.

Our World In Data

Our World In Data is an online publication by Max Roser which explores the development of human living conditions at a global scale. Our work is licensed under CC BY-SA and freely reusable by journalists or educators.
